Package io.github.edwardUL99.docker.sandbox.api

Interface DockerSandbox

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    DockerSandboxImpl
    public interface DockerSandbox
    This interface provides the main docker-sandbox API in the api package to abstract the classes of this module into an easy to use interface to allow commands to be run in sandboxed docker containers.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods

      Add environment variables to be shared between each run call.
      static DockerSandboxBuilder builder()
      Retrieve a builder to build a DockerSandboxBuilder instance to build a sandbox instance
      void cleanup()
      This method should be called in a catch block to ensure that any created containers left behind by a run call (which may have thrown the exception) are removed to avoid name conflict exceptions

      Configure the system (and the Docker client) using the provided shell and profiles.

    • Method Detail

      • configure

        void configure​(Docker.Shell shell,
               Profile... profiles)
        Configure the system (and the Docker client) using the provided shell and profiles. See DockerBuilder.withShell(Docker.Shell) and DockerBuilder.withProfiles(Profile...) for how it is configured using this method
        Parameters:
        shell - the shell the docker containers should use
        profiles - the profiles to be loaded in

      • configure

        void configure​(java.lang.String JSONFile)
        Configures the system (and the Docker client) using the JSON file. See DockerBuilder.withJSONPath(String) for info on JSON configuration
        Parameters:
        JSONFile - the path to the JSON file to load profiles from

      • addEnvironmentVariables

        void addEnvironmentVariables​(java.lang.String... envs)
        Add environment variables to be shared between each run call. They are specified in the form VARIABLE=VALUE.
        Parameters:
        envs - the list of environment variables to add

      • setBindings

        void setBindings​(Docker.Bindings bindings)
        The bindings to use for each run call
        Parameters:
        bindings - set of bindings to use for run calls

      • run

        Result run​(java.lang.String profile,
           Docker.Command command,
           WorkingDirectory.UploadedFile... uploadedFiles)
        Run the command with the specified profile, command and uploaded files with no stdin. See run(String, Docker.Command, String, WorkingDirectory.UploadedFile...)
        Parameters:
        profile - the profile to use
        command - the command to execute
        uploadedFiles - the files to upload to the working directory if any
        Returns:
        the result of the run call

      • run

        Result run​(java.lang.String profile,
           Docker.Command command,
           java.io.File stdin,
           WorkingDirectory.UploadedFile... uploadedFiles)
    throws java.io.IOException
        Run the command with the specified profile, command and uploaded files with a file as stdin. See run(String, Docker.Command, String, WorkingDirectory.UploadedFile...)
        Parameters:
        profile - the profile to use
        command - the command to execute
        stdin - the file to read the contents from and use as stdin
        uploadedFiles - the files to upload to the working directory if any
        Returns:
        the result of the run call
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if the file fails to be read

      • run

        Result run​(java.lang.String profile,
           Docker.Command command,
           java.lang.String stdin,
           WorkingDirectory.UploadedFile... uploadedFiles)
        Run the command with the specified profile, command and uploaded files with String stdin. configure(Docker.Shell, Profile...) or configure(String) and start(String) needs to be called first or else an IllegalStateException will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        profile - the profile to use
        command - the command to execute
        stdin - the standard input String to send to the docker container
        uploadedFiles - the files to upload to the working directory if any
        Returns:
        the result of the run call

      • start

        void start​(java.lang.String workingDirectory)
        Starts the system and readies it for calls to run. This call should have a subsequent call to finish() after you are finished with the run calls to ensure that resources are released. A shutdown hook is added to force a call to finish() if the program is terminated before finish() is called (e.g. by Ctrl-C).
        Parameters:
        workingDirectory - the path of the working directory on the docker container

      • finish

        void finish()
        Finishes the system by releasing any resources and resetting this class. The configure and start methods will need to be called again after this call. This method removes the shutdown hook added by start(String) if it is called normally and not by Ctrl-C

      • cleanup

        void cleanup()
        This method should be called in a catch block to ensure that any created containers left behind by a run call (which may have thrown the exception) are removed to avoid name conflict exceptions

      • getWorkingDirectory

        WorkingDirectory getWorkingDirectory()
        Retrieve the working directory object being used
        Returns:
        working directory

      • getBindings

        Docker.Bindings getBindings()
        Retrieve the bindings being used
        Returns:
        bindings

      • getDocker

        Docker getDocker()
        Get the docker client being used
        Returns:
        docker client

      • getEnvs

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getEnvs()
        Get the list of environment variables being used
        Returns:
        list of environment variables

      • builder

        static DockerSandboxBuilder builder()
        Retrieve a builder to build a DockerSandboxBuilder instance to build a sandbox instance
        Returns:
        the builder instance
